Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, Femara is the original brand and if it is written on your prescription the chemist cannot legally issue anything else. It costs the NHS £90 per pack.  If the prescription is written for letrozole the chemist is legally entitled to issue any generic letrozole from any licensed manufacturer eg RelonChem, Dr Reddy’s etc. These cost the NHS 86 pence per pack.  Where women are being dispensed their preferred generic letrozole it is because the chemist is providing additional customer service and can source that product at 86p or less per pack.   Most women tolerate the generic versions just as well as Femara and it does not make any sense for the NHS to spend £90 per month instead of 86p when there are many other pressing needs for that money. However if you find a generic letrozole that suits you it does make sense to find a chemist who understands your needs and will agree to source that version for you. The prices being quoted to you are different from those above because you are buying it privately.  For this you will need a private prescription.  The chemist can charge more or less what they like in this context.  The NHS prices are fixed. To answer your other question, the generic prices are low because these drugs have been around for a long time, the patent has expired and they are cheap to make - think paracetamol etc. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Letrozole/Femara

Posts.Content: Leolady you get Femara because it is the original brand and it is written on your prescription and the chemist cannot legally issue anything else. It costs the NHS £90 per pack.  If the prescription is written for letrozole the chemist is legally entitled to issue any generic letrozole from any licensed manufacturer eg RelonChem, Dr Reddy’s etc. These cost the NHS 86 pence per pack.  Where women are being dispensed their preferred generic letrozole it is because the chemist is providing additional customer service and can source that product at 86p or less per pack.   Most women tolerate the generic versions just as well as Femara and it does not make any sense for the NHS to spend £90 per month instead of 86p when there are many other pressing needs for that money. However if you find a generic letrozole that suits you it does make sense to find a chemist who understands your needs and will agree to source that version for you.
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Hi taralou, I’ve had two of these and I’m just about to have another one.  I didn’t notice anything at all.  Some folks have reported flu-like symptoms for a couple of days after.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Zoledronic Acid Infusion???

Posts.Content: Leolady you get Femara because it is the original brand and it is written on your prescription and the chemist cannot legally issue anything else. It costs the NHS £90 per pack.  If the prescription is written for letrozole the chemist is legally entitled to issue any generic letrozole from any licensed manufacturer eg RelonChem, Dr Reddy’s etc. These cost the NHS 86 pence per pack.  Where women are being dispensed their preferred generic letrozole it is because the chemist is providing additional customer service and can source that product at 86p or less per pack.   Most women tolerate the generic versions just as well as Femara and it does not make any sense for the NHS to spend £90 per month instead of 86p when there are many other pressing needs for that money. However if you find a generic letrozole that suits you it does make sense to find a chemist who understands your needs and will agree to source that version for you.
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Congratulations fiddler!  That is brilliant news and I'm so pleased for you & your family. xx
Posts.Title: Surgery results back!

Posts.Content: Hi.  This sounds really stressful and I'm so sorry you're going through such a difficult experience. Chemo won't kill you and there is never a good time to have it!  You can skip a few birthdays and a Christmas - your family will prefer you to be around for future ones.  You are not letting them down. If you take sensible precautions to avoid infection you have every chance of being fine.  You sound young enough to be able to cope. There's no point in trying to do all of this by yourself.  Ask family and friends to help you - that's what they are for and they will probably be pleased to be able to contribute. Be demanding of your clinical team - insist on clear answers and a clear plan, with time to ask and repeat questions.  Your breast care nurse should be totally trusted and if not, ask for a different one.  You have to put yourself first; you can be assertive and demanding without being a pain in the arse. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Delaying chemo

Posts.Content: Hi volvox, I had single mastectomy with immediate temporary reconstruction in February, full node clearance, 8 cycles chemo and 3 weeks radiotherapy. Previously I was a fit & healthy 50-something who ran regularly although not competitively.  I had to stop running during treatment but have recently started again and am completely happy that I'll be back to where I was fitness-wise in a matter of a few months. I had very few side effects from treatment - the horrors you hear about here are only one side of the story; many women have a fairly easy time but don't come here to mention it.  I did ensure that I remained active throughout treatment by lots of walking, Pilates & yoga and I also had regular sessions with a specialist macmillan physio.  I wish you the best of luck.
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Totally understand you volvox - I got huge comfort from some runners on the Breast Cancer Care forum who gave me confidence that I could keep my fitness going through treatment.  xx
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Hi stripeymaz - so good to read this!  Sometimes I've felt like a freak because I haven't spent days in bed or been rushed to hospital.  Obviously the treatment affects everyone differently but we are (understandably) told about all the things that can go wrong, which is quite scary. Best of luck for the rest of your treatment. xx
Posts.Title: It may not be as bad as you think!

Posts.Content: There is lots that I like about being bald - it saves so much time & effort in many ways.  And although I wear my wig occasionally (e.g. last week when it was COLD!) I don't think twice about going out "nude" any more.  Not a single person has looked at me funny or made any comment about it.  Yes I sometimes catch people sneaking a second look but that's just fine!
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: I knew about R1R2 but thought it unlikely I would need it so just carried on using Aveeno, which I've used for years.  Had no problems through radiotherapy at all.  I can see it's hard to justify the cost for everyone, as many people don't need it.
Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Clarkie - so sorry you're in pain and feeling down.  I don't have experience of the immediate implant but I have a tissue expander and I can relate to some of your difficulties.  My physic explained to me that the chest area is extremely sensitive and so any disruption tends to be very painful.  I'm now 4 months post-surgery and can't believe how much things have improved over the last couple of months. The physiotherapy has been the most valuable bit for me - if you can get some sessions it may help you regain movement quicker.  Best of luck. xx
Posts.Title: Implant reconstruction 4 weeks ago - advice/help please

Posts.Content: I suspect you're anxious, moody and fed up because it's perfectly natural.  I've finished chemo and waiting to start radiotherapy and I get anxious, moody and fed up on a regular basis!  Waiting for treatment can often be frustrating, along with the fact that all around you are people who talk about how awful everything is.  You don't know how you're going to cope and those close to you can probably only sympathise rather than empathise.  You'll be fine - this is a great place to rant and to find fellow ranters.  Many people cope perfectly well with treatment but remember that they are often not the ones posting here.  I found my wig at Trendco - great selection and good advice.  I too refused to visit a salon when I knew I would have chemo! Others will be along soon to offer more and maybe some kittens.  Best of luck for your treatment xxx
Posts.Title: Fed up and need a rant

Posts.Content: Hi Pollydog - hope you don’t mind me throwing in my tuppence worth.  I’m on Kacang’s side and I had everything. Chemo was ok for me but obviously it can be very hard.  In terms of risk, there are lots of non-drug things you can do to improve your odds.  Mostly to do with lifestyle - losing weight, reducing/losing alcohol, exercise, diet, reducing stress (sorry if that seems laughable given your situation). Dr Susan Love’s Breast Book (5th edition) has a lot on this. She is a US Professor of Surgery and her “bible” is often mentioned here.  We tend to focus a lot on the medical treatment because that is what we are offered by our medical teams.  I have previously commented on this forum that giving up smoking does more to increase your chances of disease-free survival than pretty much anything else. Best of luck with whatever you do.
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: It was written down on the consent form for me. I have copies of all my consent forms.
Posts.Title: How do they track and measure radiation?

Posts.Content: Oops sorry, I read that as radiotherapy not a CT scan! As you were.
Posts.Title: How do they track and measure radiation?

Posts.Content: Fantastic! Wonderful, congratulations & well done!! xx
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Ooh I know what you mean!  I had two drains and they stayed for 8 days.  I became slightly obsessed and immensely frustrated, thinking they would never leave me... But of course they did in the end.  I had a bumbag thing to carry them in but they still got caught on things.  I know when I eventually have reconstruction surgery this is going to be an issue again!
Posts.Title: My Drain and I

Posts.Content: Fantastic! Wonderful, congratulations & well done!! xx
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: I too got fed up of having to order it every month so last time I added a note (I order mine online) to request a longer prescription and now get 3 months.  There’s no harm in asking - after all we are on these drugs for years.
Posts.Title: Letrozole: have Cipla really taken over Accord?

Posts.Content: NICE seems to have restricted its approval because there are a number of uncertainties with this treatment, particularly where a patient may need additional radiotherapy treatment after the initial session.  Also because the machine costs £435k so clearly hospitals can’t just magic this up as an option for new patients.  It’s great that technology and drugs are moving forward and we are all benefiting from amazing progress in breast cancer treatment but I think we should be careful about demanding universal access to everything.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with combined Radiotherapy given "Limited Approval" TARGIT...

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab, The sensation you describe sounds familiar, although I don't get it now. Surgery (mastectomy with full node clearance and tissue expander implant) was in February.  I've just started running again.  It's not what you asked but M&S post surgery extra high impact sports bras have been fantastic for me.  I've been lucky to have regular physio since surgery and I'm convinced it has made all the difference to my recovery. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi NikkiS, I do think all the forums are slightly skewed towards the negative - understandably, as people with problems are asking for advice and reassurance!  I've had Mx with tissue expander and experienced no problems at all.  I'm hoping that the final reconstruction will also be problem-free.  I'm similar age to you, pretty fit and healthy, smaller bust though (34A) so I'm going up a cup!  Best of luck. xx
Posts.Title: Advice Please....Reconstruction or Not??

Posts.Content: I had an appointment at a local Nat West branch a few months ago and it was quite a long one. Half way through I asked if I could use a toilet and was duly shown where it was (no Macmillan card involved).  Pacca's experience could be a local decision based on the branch's facilities rather than "company policy".
Posts.Title: Macmillan Toilet Card

Posts.Content: I had surgery (single mx, node clearance and recon with expander) in the evening and could have gone home the next day but I didn't feel ready so stayed in two nights.  I had two drains that were taken out on day 8.  Consultants vary as to whether they use drains and if they do, how little they want to see in the drain before taking it out.  I was advised not to drive for 3 weeks and I nearly made it!  I was up & active pretty much straight away but without any heavy lifting for several weeks.  Certainly OK by 6 weeks but being careful about putting any strain on it.  Luckily it was left side - right side would have been much more difficult. In terms of how it feels from the inside, it's comfortable enough but does feel alien and I'll be glad to have it replaced with my own tissue in due course.
Posts.Title: Strattice reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Yes, I had this.  I'm in the private system but my plastic surgeon works mainly in NHS and does it routinely.  Is there anything specific you want to know about it?
Posts.Title: Strattice reconstruction?

Posts.Content: I didn't have any bruising.  However I still have a bit of blue left from the sentinel node biopsy I had 7 months ago!  I didn't have nipple sparing.  The scar itself is quite faded now 6 months post-surgery and the shape is good. To be honest I was happy with the idea of mastectomy because I wanted the cancer to be gone and not to have to worry about any being left behind.
Posts.Title: Strattice reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Max, I went for mastectomy because I have small breasts and dense lumpy ones at that!  A lumpectomy would have removed about half of the breast if not more.  I also felt that I would be worried about any recurrence being detected, given the nature of the breast tissue.  I'm glad I chose it.  There is some evidence that lumpectomy patients have overall better outcomes but of course it's very complex.  Dr Susan Love explains it well in her Breast Book.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: The decision

Posts.Content: Head hair started to grow back quite fast - other hair not!  Lost almost all eyelashes. No bone pain.  General aches & pains started 2-3 days afterwards for a couple of days, sorted with paracetamol & ibuprofen. No weight gain or weight loss throughout 4xFEC + 4xT. Generally felt T was easier than FEC. As you said, everyone is different!
Posts.Title: Truth about doxetaxel

Posts.Content: Sorry - autocorrect changed Maz to Max!
Posts.Title: The decision

Posts.Content: Hi maxinem2 you’re just a few months ahead of me! I see my oncologist every 6 months but that’s in the private system. Are you anywhere near menopause? I will change from tamoxifen to an aromatase inhibitor soon, as I’ve now gone through menopause - was that discussed for you?  You should have a written care plan at any rate explaining ongoing treatment and follow up points - this is in the NICE guidance.  If not perhaps ask GP to request it for you.
Posts.Title: Two years since Chemo what now

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, I've had 6 treatments so far via cannula (4 FEC and 2 T) and will have another 2.  I've had no problems at all.  My veins are not particularly special.  The FEC can make them a bit sore but massage and time has sorted that.  If the nurses are skilled at inserting cannulas there shouldn't be any pain.  Leaking is serious but shouldn't happen and they check very carefully to ensure the cannula is inserted properly.
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line

Posts.Content: I agree with elements of both views here.  Totally agree it's important to be an assertive patient who can ask questions, challenge decisions where the rationale is not clear and ask about alternatives.  However to say that "only you can know what's right for you" is a bit trite I think.  Reading research papers and experiencing a single cancer journey as a patient does not compare with 15+ years of medical study & training and often many years of specialised practice and ongoing research, which the consultants we see have under their belts.  Sometimes the comments made on this forum do come across as "dissing" NHS doctors.  For me, the best treatment plan is one which both patient and clinician are convinced is going to have the best outcome.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: NHS pays £1.27 for 28 tablets of anastrazole.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I support chloecat's right to post about her experiences without prejudice; I think it's a brave thing to share her journey here and she shouldn't be ridiculed.  Neither should those of us who choose the conventional route be called cowards. To expect any treatment for any condition to have 100% success rate over 5 years is frankly ridiculous.  News flash - you could die from all sorts of things over the next 5 years, nothing to do with cancer.  Particularly if you are older and like any other cancer, prevalence rates rise with age.  Many cancer patients will have other medical conditions as well as cancer. The reason the NHS provides evidence-based medical treatment is precisely because there is evidence behind it.  The problem with alternative treatments is that the evidence for their effectiveness is usually either weak or absent.  For those of us funding the NHS it is therefore unacceptable to include them in the standard treatment pathway. I will also repeat myself on the subject of "research".  Google searches and reading a few papers does not constitute clinical research or replace many years of study and training.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Exemastane NHS price for 30 days is £8.10 Everolimus NHS price is not available because manufacturers have agreed confidential discounts with NICE in order to allow use in certain cancers. Both drugs are "generic" so don't worry you're not breaking the bank!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I totally agree we should respect each other's choices and offer support where it's sought.  I will say though that Chloecat has written a couple of times "why would anyone choose conventional treatment?" including  in a post on page 1.  I doubt she meant it as derogatory to those on the conventional path but it can be read as such.  Clearly it's a sensitive topic!  This thread has made me think, which is a good thing.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Any drug excreted via the urine can affect its smell.  The more concentrated the urine, the more you will notice.  I'm currently on chemo and often my urine smells utterly disgusting.  Agree it's worth mentioning and also thinking about other things you are consuming.  It's not always the drugs! Kadcyla is a combination of Herceptin and a newer molecule called emtansine.
Posts.Title: Smelly urine! (Sorry!)

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, I'm in my 50s and a keen runner (10-15k rather than marathons).  I stopped because I had an immediate temporary reconstruction with tissue expander, so have had to be quite careful.  However like others I've kept up the exercise via fast walking during my 4 cycles of FEC.  The F is a bugger as it affects your heart so my resting heart rate shoots up after each treatment then settles but never back to normal, so be grateful you're not having that!  I'm ready to get on my bike now as I can put all my weight on my mastectomy side arm but just haven't been out yet!  The next 4 cycles I will have docetaxel which can cause muscle & joint pain as well as fatigue but I'm pretty determined to maintain a level of fitness if I can.  I also do Pilates every week which is great.  On the Breast Cancer Care forum there is a thread in the Hope & Inspiration section called Running on Treatment - I recommend having a look as it gave me a huge amount of comfort!  Best of luck. xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Yes I have zoledronic acid (Zometa) infusions every 6 months - had 4 so far.  It’s an infusion rather than an injection.  Takes a couple of hours from start to finish.  I haven’t experienced any side effects at all, although some people report flu-like symptoms for a couple of days afterwards.
Posts.Title: Bone injections

Posts.Content: Yes I had mine microbladed just after my first chemo so about 7 months and they are fabulous! Really great shape and colour.  If I'd known, I would have done it years ago as my own eyebrows are a bit rubbish.  I had a top-up after about 3 months and will keep topping them up as necessary.  Go for it!
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows post-chemo?

Posts.Content: Mistymoley you can't specify a generic on a prescription - that's the whole point.  So-called "branded generics" are a different matter but this does not apply for letrozole.  Greenhead could ask to be prescribed Femara but as she says, this costs the NHS just over £90 for 30 tablets compared with just over £2 for a generic prescription.  Most people happily tolerate the generic versions of drugs, so I'm not sure I understand the comment about cancer recurrence.  Many of the chemotherapy standard drugs (e.g. FEC-T) are also generic and produced by several different manufacturers, at different prices.  Like it or not, pharmaceuticals are a commercial global industry.
Posts.Title: Sandoz Letrozole - Boots unable to supply

Posts.Content: It may be helpful to understand the pharmacist's situation here. Letrozole is classed as a category M drug which means that the NHS sets the price reimbursed to the dispenser (i.e. Boots or whoever). Currently it is £1.02 for 14 tablets.  So Boots must buy it for that price or less from a wholesaler in order not to lose money.  If Sandoz is charging £1.50 and Accord is charging 95p then Boots will buy in the Accord version.  Exchange rates often affect this situation, as do manufacturing cycles and stock issues and other factors. The only way to ensure getting the version that seems to suit you is to persuade your GP to prescribe it as Femara.
Posts.Title: Sandoz Letrozole - Boots unable to supply

Posts.Content: Dragonfly46 I feel for you - your life is in their hands and it’s so important to have trust in whatever treatment is planned for you.  Carolyn28 is right, they should be discussing you in a multidisciplinary team but I know from experience that not all clinicians take this as seriously as they could.  Your case is clearly unusual and even more important that everyone agrees what the best treatment plan is.  Could you ask your BCN about the MDT meetings and who’s involved?  I found my clinicians to be very open about this system.  If they are not, that would be a concern and definitely something to take to PALS.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Conflicting advice from my oncologist and my consultant.

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn, I’ve had 3 of these infusions now and can honestly say I haven’t noticed anything at all in the way of side effects.  I was not advised to take anything beforehand or afterwards.  I didn’t have it until I’d finished chemo and radio though. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Starting Zolendronate

Posts.Content: Very sad stories here. I do think some friends and family find it hard to know what to say, for fear of saying the wrong thing.  My experience of healthcare professionals however has been that all bar one have been wonderful, caring, attentive and very welcoming of questions.  The one person who wasn't any of those things was, ironically, a nurse.
Posts.Title: Is it just me? - I'm just ranting really ;)

Posts.Content: I haven't had any family or close friends go through treatment for cancer, so before my diagnosis I had no idea about any of it.  I sometimes wonder how I would have behaved if the boot was on the other foot - if it was my sister, cousin, friend, neighbour with cancer not me.  Cancer is still, for many people, very scary with lots of taboos and unknowns.  Also, I suspect some people don't ask me about it because they know I'm a private person and don't want to intrude or upset me.  That's why these forums are great, I agree!
Posts.Title: Is it just me? - I'm just ranting really ;)

Posts.Content: Not gargle in the throat but swill around for as long as you can.  Then swallow.  And you should take it four times a day.
Posts.Title: Nystan

Posts.Content: I’ve been on tamoxifen for 5 months (various different generic versions) without any problems. I take it at bedtime.  I get hot flushes but as I’m mid-50s I would expect that anyway.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen - Side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha, Whether you are offered chemo or not depends on all sorts of factors and the oncologist or nurse should explain this to you carefully so that you understand why you are being offered it and how it will increase your chances of survival.  However the regime (drugs and number of doses) doesn't really depend on the number of cancerous nodes.  Don't panic - in spite of what you read on these forums, chemo is really not that bad! Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Results end chemo

Posts.Content: Grogg pharmaceutical companies make money by investing huge amounts of money in clinical trials to prove that their drugs work. There is no need to discredit "cheap natural remedies".  Most of us here are alive or will live much longer because of research done by pharmaceutical companies.  Modern medicine is amazing.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: If you want to look at evidence based treatments go to the NICE guidance or to the US cancer.org guidelines.  The newest drugs tend to be for the more advanced and complex areas of cancer rather than "standard" cases where the evidence is well established. I'm having treatment privately - the treatment pathway and regimen is the same as it would be in the NHS, it's just the drugs I get for avoiding/combating side effects that are newer/more expensive.
Posts.Title: HER2 positive and oestrogen receptor positive

Posts.Content: Hi youngatheart.  There is a lot of confusion about this topic.  The only “brand” is Femara and if the GP prescribes this it must be dispensed.  It costs the NHS around £90 per pack that is reimbursed to the pharmacist.  The rest of the names people use here are the names of manufacturing companies who make lots of different generic drugs.  A generic pack of letrozole currently costs the NHS 89p and this is the fixed price that is reimbursed to the pharmacist.  If the pharmacist can’t buy it for 89p or less s/he will lose money.  So pharmacies are always looking for the best price which is why we get different packs all the time.  Larger pharmacy chains with big buying power may be more likely to help you out if you find one that suits you but it is not your right.
Posts.Title: Clenmark Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Amy, I’ve had private treatment via insurance and as others have said, the cost depends on what diagnostics and treatment you need.  I had an initial sentinel node biopsy followed by single mastectomy and axillary node clearance with immediate temporary reconstruction with tissue expander, then 8 cycles of chemotherapy and 15 cycles of radiotherapy.  I had a number of scans and tests including an echocardiogram.  I had about 15 sessions of physiotherapy and 4 sessions of counselling with a specialist cancer therapist.  All my chemo drugs and post-chemo injections were covered by the insurance but I got a variety of drugs from my NHS GP to counter the side effects of chemo which would not have been covered by my insurance.  I’ve also had 3 x 6 monthly bisphosphonate infusions at the hospital.  I have tamoxifen from my GP. The bill currently stands at around £70k.  I had no complications, no admissions for infections during chemo, no problems or unscheduled treatments.  I do have 3 consultants (breast surgeon, plastic surgeon, oncologist).  I have not yet had reconstruction surgery. Hope that helps.  Good luck xx
Posts.Title: BC stage 3B - private treatment
